text: you can make just about anything with a
3d printer these days even medical
devices and implants but most of these
objects are rigid recreating complex
soft tissues like the structures that
make up the human heart is much more
complicated Carnegie Mellon researchers
are meeting the challenge by injecting
hydrogels made of proteins and
carbohydrates into similar gels that
support the new tissue as it prints
first they make 3d images of the tissue
and use computer-aided design to create
a template then the printer goes to work
in voila in under an hour a functional
coronary artery is complete it's even
capable of transporting fluids like
blood the researchers have also printed
an anatomically correct miniature human
brain you might not be able to order a
new brain anytime soon but soft tissue
replacements customized to each
patient's medical needs could be just
around the corner
you
